author: chris2_2_2
content: Youtube ‚Äúethereum foundation‚Äù

author: killari.
content: https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/892088344438255616/988633522736594974 <@301186049323958275> you want the keys to be as small as possible while still being secure for performance reasons

author: sky.cactus
content: I thought there was some special thing that made 224 significantly easier than 225 bits.  Am I mistaken?

author: sky.cactus
content: Like there was some threshold across which stuff suddenly got much harder.

author: killari.
content: ah, I am not aware of that

author: killari.
content: generally they are less than 256 bits as ethereum uses that, and you want to be able to store the key on less than 256. Then you want to find some number that is easy to do calculations with

author: killari.
content: the ones that are easier to do calculations are close to some power of two, so maybe there are more primes near power of twos with 224 bits than 225?

author: sky.cactus
content: You mean `224 bits` is `2^6 * 7`, while `225` bits doesn't have any factors of `2`?

author: killari.
content: yeah

author: kevaundray
content:
<@301186049323958275> I'm not working on the merge directly, so <#892088344438255616> is read-only for me. In regards to 

https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/892088344438255616/988633836193742888

I think less than 256 bits would generally be better for proving time:

As an analogy, in a 64 bit architecture, the word size is 64 bits, so if you have a datatype which requires more than 64 bits to encode its information, then you'd need multiple words. Like a u65 would need 2 64 bit words. Also adding a u65 would have more complexity to it than adding a u64 or something than is less than 64 bits.

For zk proofs, we usually have a word size that is just less than 256 bits, so to encode a 256 bit number we would also need 2 words/field elements. If its not used too often, it might be okay I think, I'd need to check the exact system/usage to determine whether the blowup may be significant.

Reasons I would not go for 234 bits would be because it may reduce the security of the system as a whole, If we are using 234 bits or even less in other places, then this may not be a valid concern though.

author: yokem55
content: A quick question about this - https://discord.com/channels/595666850260713488/892088344438255616/988616072842330132 (the execution client overwriting the jwt secret on each startup): Does this effectively mean that if an operator wishes to run the execution client and consensus client on separate physical machines, there needs to be an out of band synchronization on this file? Or is there a method to lock the file (simple ro *nix permissions?) and only distribute it once between machines?

author: enriavil1
content: Hello I am from the erigon team, and just got told that Prysm supports Sepolia with a TTD of `100000000000000000000000` and an empty blockhash for TBH and was wondering if other CL clients will adopt the same number for now or not?

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> Any number exceedingly high should work as a config param currently. This just ensures it won't be hit until a precise number is decided (to be discussed on Friday acd)

author: ajsutton
content: There is a number which is roughly that in the beacon chain config for sepolia so all clients are likely using the same number.  You'll get warnings if the TTD doesn't match up between EL and CL.

author: ajsutton
content: "roughly that" as in, I haven't tried counting the zeros.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: Are ELs planning on releasing updated binaries before the Sepolia TTD?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Since Sepolia is mostly only run by us, we don't plan to for the fake TTD, only for the real TTD (most likely)

author: ajsutton
content: Teku has a release out with sepolia support included now, but it doesn't have the final TTD (because it hasn't been set).  We'll need to use an override for the final TTD initially as it will likely need to be applied faster than we'd want to get a release out.
